item.title: About
item.description:
About

,

This is not my job, it is my passion.

,
  1. Currently: Full-Stack ASP.NET C# Software Engineer with VIVA Physicians
  2. B.S. in Computer Science from Chapman University (2016)
  3. I have been fortunate to work in several areas of the stack and I love it all
  4. I have only disliked one language so far, Objective C
  5. I do no re-invent, I extend off what is available and innovate.
  6. At a certain point I stopped wondering how a piece of software was made, to knowing how it was done and how I could make it better.
  7. Self-motivated, and self-driven to use the skills i have, and continue to develop to bring software that benefits well-being or quality of life
  8. I will not develop for you if I don’t believe in the ethics of the software, i.e. the micro transaction drain our users wallet approach is not what I am interested in.
  9. I also will also not work in an environment where I cannot wear a jeans and t-shirt to work.
  10. I’m not book-smart, I am code-smart
,

I also am a big fan of hardware and building computers, snowboarding, dogs, and hockey.

,

Above all I am lucky to have a great girlfriend that puts up with me coding for days straight and having 12 Philips hue RGB lights in my room.

item.title: Software Engineer: Full-Stack ASP.NET C# MVC (Remote)
item.description:
Software Engineer: Full-Stack ASP.NET C# MVC (Remote)

,

Employer: VIVA Physicians

,

Daily workflow:

,
  • - Languages: C#, JavaScript, SQL, ([CS]HTML/CSS)
  • - Frameworks: ASP.NET Razor/MVC, AngularJS, EntityFramework,
  • - Code Management: Team Foundation Server (TFS) w/ Git
  • - Site Management: Internet Information Services (IIS)

item.title: Map-Wall Live January 14th, 2017 at the California Science Center in Los Angeles!
item.description:
,

Map-Wall Live January 14th, 2017 at the California Science Center in Los Angeles!

,

We went live January 14th, 2017! Check out the exhibit I did all the coding for at the California Science Center in Los Angeles. Map-Wall is simple to use and requires users to point the spotlight at one of the several points of interest on the map and press the trigger, which causes information on the monitor to be displayed about the selected point.
This projects backend was written in all C++ that leveraged ultraDMX Micro for interfacing with DMX512, SEI Absoluter Encoder Comm Protocol for reading (X,Y) coordinates, and U-HID for the LED Push Buttons on the spotlight device.
The frontend parses JSON generated by an Excel file filled out by the exhibit currator which the code supports English and Spanish which users can change with a button press on the base of the device. The frontend is generated on the fly using basic HTML,CSS, and Javascript leveraging the dojo toolkit. All points are pre-calibrated for each station with extra space for more in the future.
This has been one of my favorite projects I have done thus far. It is is awesome to see people of all ages interacting with and enjoying the exhibit!
